We just passed the SECURE Act, to strengthen retirement for American families.

I took to the floor to explain why we needed to pass this bill to fix tax hikes on Gold Star families, college students, Native Americans, and first responder families imposed by the GOP tax law: pic.twitter.com/A3VuCNZiTQ

I introduced a fix for the tax hike on first responder families. My VA colleague @RepElaineLuria introduced the Gold Star Families Tax Relief Act to fix the widows' tax (I'm a cospsonsor).  https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/05/02/navy-vet-lawmaker-introduces-measure-repeal-tax-hike-gold-star-families.html … 

The SECURE Act fixes all of these tax hikes. I will vote YES. 8/8 pic.twitter.com/sOWTTTmqHL

I had constituents contact me whose families were hurt by several of these provisions, and there were tens of thousands across the country. This is why you don't rush huge legislation like a tax bill, why you take the time and listen to everyone: so you can get it right. 7/

The GOP tax law even increased taxes on survivor benefits paid by state or local governments to children of first responders killed in the line of duty. 6/ https://www.politico.com/newsletters/morning-tax/2019/05/20/more-kiddie-tax-to-fix-438223 …

The same provision of the GOP tax law dealt a devastating blow to many Native American families: "...doubling or tripling the tax rate paid by [some] young Native Americans on financial support they receive from their tribal governments." 5/ https://www.hklaw.com/publications/tax-parity-kiddie-tax-exemption-still-needed-for-indian-country-06-04-2018/ …

The GOP tax bill taxes unearned income to these children as if they were wealthy under an old provision called "the Kiddie Tax."

It didn't just hit survivor benefits of military families- it also got many low income students who receive scholarships. 4/ https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/17/us/politics/college-scholarships-tax-increases.html …

Dependent children of servicemembers, many of them killed in action, getting tax bills that suddenly ballooned by thousands of dollars because of what one of the legislation's authors says was a "mistake."

Military families call it "the widows' tax." 3/ https://taskandpurpose.com/congress-widows-tax-gold-star-families …

As you may remember, Republicans rushed their massive tax cut that mostly helped the rich through without holding hearings or listening to our input.

After it was passed some Gold Star families discovered that they had been hit with huge tax increases. 2/ https://thehill.com/opinion/national-security/439790-congress-must-do-away-with-the-militarys-widows-tax …

Today we are voting on the SECURE Act, which would help more Americans retire with financial peace of mind.

This bill will also fix terrible problems created by the GOP tax bill which badly hurt Gold Star families, first responders, college students, and Native Americans. 1/

I believe that my constituents are right, and I support the initiation of an impeachment inquiry to examine evidence of criminal acts committed by President Trump.

The most important consideration for me in evaluating whether this course of action is correct has been the views of my constituents.

Their belief in the need to launch an impeachment inquiry – as expressed to me in calls, letters, and conversations – has grown to a crescendo.

Congressman Amash’s brave public statement makes support for an impeachment inquiry bipartisan, and I have privately spoken to other Republicans who believe he is right but are unwilling to say so publicly.

...and I have every confidence in the ability of my colleagues on the House Judiciary Committee and in the Speaker and her leadership team to pursue such an inquiry if they determine that it is the proper course.

From the first time I was asked about impeachment I have always said that I believed that such a serious action must be fully justified by the facts, must be done with great care, and it must have bipartisan support. I believe the facts fully justify an impeachment inquiry...

...but the President’s illegal cover-up, most recently evidenced by his preventing the Secretary of the Treasury and the former White House Counsel from honoring Congressional subpoenas, leaves us little recourse to do so.

We are aware of other potential crimes committed by this President, including tax fraud and violations of campaign finance laws, both alleged under oath by his former attorney. 

Congress must investigate these allegations to determine their veracity...

The behavior described in the redacted Mueller Report meets every standard for the classification of ‘obstruction of justice’ of which I am aware.

He has compounded that fact by engaging in illegal stonewalling of Congress as my colleagues and I have engaged in oversight.
President Trump has shown utter contempt for the Constitution from the moment he took office, but we are now faced with evidence of actions that strongly resemble high crimes and misdemeanors.

Endorsing such a course is not easy, and I do not do so lightly, but I believe that the President has left Congress no other option.

When I came to Congress I swore an oath ‘to defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic.’
The time has come for the House of Representatives to open an impeachment inquiry into the conduct of President Trump. pic.twitter.com/WXOmMCakl0

We don't have a lot of time, but we do have a solution. We can pass the Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act to #ProtectWildlifeCorridors and help save our planet. 

Here's a bit more about how the bill protects species. Thanks for reading! 8/8 https://twitter.com/wildlandsnetwrk/status/1129174840236302337 …

So we just introduced the Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act again, for a third time.

Lo and behold, my colleague @VernBuchanan, a Republican from Florida, just became the second cosponsor of the bill in the House and made the legislation bipartisan for the first time. 7/

Now it's 2019 and we just learned that time to protect species is running out even faster than we thought. A UN report assembled by hundreds of scientists from around the world said that extinctions are occurring at a terrifying rate, and accelerating. 6/ https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/06/climate/biodiversity-extinction-united-nations.html …

Then the following year Dr. Wilson came back to Capitol Hill to speak about corridors and a huge number of people came out to hear him. One of those people was on the stage with us: @SenatorTomUdall. He introduced a Senate version of the bill. Progress. 5/ https://twitter.com/RepDonBeyer/status/922874532867608576 …

The idea developed into the Wildlife Corridors Conservation Act, with help from wildlife advocates at @EOWilsonFndtn, @wildlandsnetwrk, @Defenders, and elsewhere. I introduced it in 2016, with little reaction. 4/

Dr. Wilson was deeply concerned about the rapid rate of species loss largely due to the destruction of habitats. He had an idea; that we create a system of wildlife corridors to protect habitats and strengthen the genetic stock of threatened species. 3/ https://twitter.com/RepDonBeyer/status/1072595476329979905 …

Several years ago I got a visit from a legendary scientist, Dr. E.O. Wilson. Dr. Wilson a myrmecologist (the study of ants) famous for coining the term "biodiversity" and pioneering sociobiology as a scientific branch. 2/

"E.O. Wilson Goes To Washington"
